How does this work?
Linux Essentials
LPIC-1 101
LPIC-1 102
GPL v3.0 License Text
Linux Tutor Companion App
About
About this App
Developed and maintained by:\nNiclas Rautenhaus
Contact me at: info@linux-tutor.de
Further information at:\nwww.linux-tutor.de

This app is for educational purposes only and does not pursue commercial interests. \nThis app is Ad-free and will always be. \nIf you however would like to donate a few bucks, feel free to do so on Flattr:
Manual - Step 1
Manual - Step 2
Manual - Step 3

Choose a category:
• Linux Essentials
• LPIC-1 101
• LPIC-1 102
Choose an item from the list, e.g "Distributions"

You are presented with 6 tabs, numbered from 1 to 6. These stand for:
• 1: Topic
• 2: Introduction
• 3: Tasks
• 4: Approach
• 5: Materials
• 6: Evaluation
The source code of this app can be obtained by visiting\nhttps://github.com/Linux-Tutor/LinuxTutorCompanionApp.git\nThe source code is provided under the terms of the GPL v3.0.
Distributions

Key subjects are: 
• Open-Source-Philosophy
• Distributions
• Choosing a distribution
• Support cycles
• GUI vs. CLI

These tasks deal with selected Linux distributions, the question on which systems Linux is deployed, as well as basic principles of Open Source.\n\nFurthermore, a look is taken at maintenance cycles, the differences between a CLI and a GUI and the key differences between the three big OS Windows, Mac OS and Linux.
Open Source

Key subjects are: 
• Desktop applications
• Server applications
• Package management tools
• Licenses
• FSF, OSI

These tasks deal with some desktop and server applications, as well as the fact that many of them are Open Source!

Furthermore the basics of different package managers are discussed.
Eventually, the Open Source licensing models, the Free Software Foundaition and the Open Source Initiative are dealt with.
Working with Linux

Key subjects are: 
• Knowledge of the Desktop
• First steps with the CLI
• Commercial Linux

These tasks deal with the active usage of a Linux desktop, but also the CLI is slowly approached.\n\nCommercial linux distributions, privacy and considerations when choosing a password are also topics.
Working on the CLI

Key subjects are: 
• Basic knowledge of the Shell
• Structure and input of commands
• Command options
• Variables, Globbing, Search patterns

These tasks deal with an introduction to the Linux shell.
In addition to that, the syntax of a command and how it is entered into the shell is being discussed.

Furthermore, command options, variables, globbing and search patterns will be a topic.
Getting help on the CLI

Key subjects are: 
• Man(pages)
• Info
• locate, whatis, whereis
These tasks deal with an introduction to the manpages - the number one way to get help.\n\nMoreover, commands to read documentations and commands to search and find files will be shed a light upon.
Directories and logfiles

Key subjects are: 
• Files and directories
• Hidden files and folders
• Specifying paths
• Navigating the directory structure

These tasks deal with the different directories of a Linux system and important files of it.

Hidden files and folders as well as different ways how to reference to a file will be a topic.
Additionally, you will learn how to navigate in the directory structure.
Archiving

Key subjects are: 
• Archiving files and folders
• Compression techniques and archive types
• Tools for archiving
• Extracting archives

These tasks focus on how to archive files and directories.

Moreover, different compression types and tools are handled.
Eventually, exercises about compression tools and how to unzip files will be given.
Input- and output redirection

Key subjects are: 
• Pipelines
• Redirection of input and output
• STDIN, STDOUT, STDERR
• File filtering, file processing
The topics of this lection are: pipes, input- and output redirection, the three text streams and data filtering.
Scripting

Key subjects are: 
• File processing, File editing
• Basic shell scripts
• Loops, Return values, Arguments
The exercises are about editing and processing text files, as well as creating shell scripts.\n\nFurthermore we will dive into loops, arguments and return values.
Hardware
Key subjects are: \n\u2022 Hardware\n\u2022 Drivers
This lesson is about hardware and drivers.
Storing data

Key subjects are: 
• Kernel, Processes, PIDs
• syslog, klog, dmesg
• Libraries, Logfile directories

This lesson is about the role of the kernel, processes and PIDs.

Moreover the exercises will handle syslog, klog and the ringbuffer dmesg.
In addition to that, libraries and logfile directories will be looked at.
The PC in a network

Key subjects are: 
• Internet, Networks, Router
• DNS
• Network settings, Configuration files
• route, ping, netstat, ifconfig

This lesson is about computers integrated into a network, and the necessary essentials.
We will discuss the Internet, networks in general and the function and role of routers and DNS.

You will perform tasks that handle the configuration files, setting network parameters and learn some commands like route, ping, netstat and ifconfig.
Users; managing users and groups

Key subjects are: 
• Root, system users, normal users
• Commands to manage users/groups
• System files for users/groups, UIDs, GIDs

In this lesson you will learn what the different users to on a Linux system.

The focus is on the root user, but also the built in system users and their characteristics will be pointed out.
Additionally, you will learn about GIDs and UIDs, learn commands to manage users and groups and how the configuration files look like.
File permissions
Key subjects are: \n\u2022 File permissions\n\u2022 Rights management
Special files and directories

Key subjects are: 
• Hard-/Soft-links
• /etc, /var, /tmp
• Special permissions

This lesson is about special files of directories.

The concept of hard- and soft links and the role of the /var /etc and /tmp directory will be of interest.
Eventually special permissions and their relation to the stated directories above will be shed a light upon.

Do research on the basis of the given materials and answer the questions, with the help of the questionnaire.

When you finished with the exercises, continue with the evaluation and compare your answers to the ones stated in the sample solution.
The questionnaire can be found in the "materials" tab; the sample solution in the tab "evaluation".

Discuss your results with another student.
What is different or is the same in your answers?

When the results have been discussed, compare your findings to the sample solution.

The LinuxTutor Companion App is a offline version of the corresponding website.
